response.original_title: Singing the Shapes: Songs of the Enduring Sacred Harp
response.overview: The raw, untethered sound of shape-note singing is unmistakable—and the systems that keep it alive are equally distinct. Rooted in an 1844 American songbook called The Sacred Harp, this unaccompanied choral practice has persisted for centuries entirely outside the cultural mainstream. Unlike orchestras, bands, or choirs, there are no set members, auditions, rehearsals, or performances. Instead, Sacred Harp singings are participatory gatherings with no audience, where whoever shows up is invited to contribute—by lending their voice, leading a song, or sharing a dish.
response.title: Singing the Shapes: Songs of the Enduring Sacred Harp
